Package assignment1

Class Polygon

java.lang.Object
assignment1.Polygon
All Implemented Interfaces:
Transformable
Direct Known Subclasses:
Pentagon, Quadrilateral, Triangle
public abstract class Polygon
extends java.lang.Object
implements Transformable
The following abstract class Polygon defines general methods and properties that are shared by all polygons. This class is further inherited by concrete classes such as Triangle, Quadrilateral, Pentagon as they define concrete polygon structures.

  • Constructor Details

    • Polygon

      public Polygon​(java.util.Set<Point> ptSet)
      The constructor initializes the array points. It does so by taking as input @param ptSet which is a parameter of type Set. Specifically, A LinkedHashSet made up of points should be passed in as input to preserve order of points in the vertices array. Elements from @param ptSet are added to the array vertices.
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if we try to instantiate a particular kind of polygon with inappropriate number of points/vertices. For example, an IllegalArgumentException is thrown if we try to instantiate a Triangle with more or less than 3 Points/vertices.

  • Method Details

    • appropriateNumberOfVertices

      public abstract int appropriateNumberOfVertices()
      Abstract method which is implemented in concrete subclasses of the superclass Polygon
      Returns:
      the appropriate number of vertices for a particular polygon. For example, return 3 for triangles, 4 for quadrilaterals, etc.

    • computePerimeter

      public double computePerimeter()
      The following method computes the perimeter for any polygon at hand. It does so by taking the distance between each subsequent Point object in the vertices array and then taking the sum. The method keeps in mind the circular relationship between polygon vertices, i.e. for a triangle defined by vertices [a, b, c], the perimeter will be the same for another triangle defined by vertices [c, a, b].
      Returns:
      the perimeter for the desired polygon.

    • contains

      public boolean contains​(Point pt)
      The following method checks if a particular Point exists in the Polygon. Specifically, it checks if a particular Point is an element of the vertices array defining the polygon.
      Parameters:
      pt - , A point type object. This is the point that we are checking if the polygon contains.
      Returns:
      a boolean value. Return true if @param pt exists in the polygon (i.e. the vertices array) and returns false otherwise.

    • translate

      public void translate​(double x2, double y2, double z2)
      The following method translates all the points in the vertices array which define the polygon. Translation is done by adding the @params x2, y2, z2 the Point object's coordinates for each Point type object belonging to the vertices array. This leads to translation of each point in the array vertices defining the polygon.
      Specified by:
      translate in interface Transformable

    • scale

      public void scale​(double sfPol)
      The following method scales all the points in the vertices array which define the polygon. Scaling of a point is done by multiplying the coordinates (x,y,z) of a Point to a common factor. @param sfPol is the scaling factor which scales each point in the verices array. This leads to scaling of each point in the point in the array vertices defining the polygon.
      Specified by:
      scale in interface Transformable

    • equals

      public boolean equals​(java.lang.Object obj)
      The following method checks if 2 Polygons are equal. 2 polygons are equal if they contain the same vertices (Points) in their vertices array in the same order. To elaborate, a Polygon defined by vertices [a, b, c] is equal to another polygon defined by [c, a, b] as their vertices connect in the same manner which forms the same polygon.
      Overrides:
      equals in class java.lang.Object
      Parameters:
      obj - , this could be an object of any class; this is the object we compare our calling object against to check for equality.
      Returns:
      a boolean value. Returns true if both the calling object and input parameter object are equal and returns false otherwise.

    • hashCode

      public int hashCode()
      The following method returns a unique hash code for each Polygon. The main idea here is that 2 equal Polygons should have the same hash code whereas 2 unequal polygons should have different hash codes.
      Overrides:
      hashCode in class java.lang.Object
